summary: Michael Stratton appears to be an individual involved in intelligence gathering or observation related to the Fair Play for Cuba Committee (FPCC) in 1961. He is reporting to C/EAB/OS and Jack Kennedy about Court Wood, a student with pro-Castro sentiments who returned from Cuba under the FPCC's sponsorship. Stratton is maintaining a relationship with Wood and informing his office of subsequent visits. He seeks guidance from Jack Kennedy regarding his relationship with Court Wood and Wood's father. There is also a collection of memorandum references related to Stratton and the FPCC, suggesting ongoing involvement or reporting.
significance: Michael Stratton's significance in the JFK assassination context lies in his involvement with the Fair Play for Cuba Committee, an organization that Lee Harvey Oswald was associated with. His role in monitoring Court Wood, a pro-Castro student involved with the FPCC, suggests an intelligence interest in the organization. The FPCC's connection to Oswald makes any intelligence gathering related to the group potentially relevant to understanding the events surrounding the assassination.
